column8: other sources identify his birthdate as 9-15-1890 and the birthplace as Sunny Ville, also in Clarendon Parish; Cooper says that McKay was born in Sunny Ville in 1890 and left at the age of 7
enrolled in trade school in Kingston beginning in January 1907; the school was destroyed by the earthquake on January 14, 1907
works as an apprentice to a master craftsman for two years; meets Walter Jekyll there

column8: "I worked as a janitor and houseman at the D.K.E. House and the Hanover Inn from 1915 until the spring of 1916, and my only connection with the college was that I used to go to the library at night sometimes to read.‚Äù, letter to Harold Rugg, librarian at Dartmouth, 1921, papers of Harold Rugg-Dartmouth College
Spent this time period working on the Pennsylvania Railroad and traveling throughout the US.

unable to find employment, McKay enters Camp Greycourt, a former women's prison "that had been converted the previous May to a place of rehabilitiation for the down-and-out of the city's municipal lodging houses" (Cooper 301)

column8: suffers from a stroke while working as a riveter in a federal shipyard in Newark, New Jersey; spends the summer of 1943 recovering in a friend's Connecticut country cottage (Cooper 356-357).
spends the end of 1943 recovering in the hospital and the 135th Street YMCA
